titleStmt.title:
The grand Question debated,
1Hamilton's Bawn, is a large old House, on Sir Arthur Atchison's Estate, about two miles, from his Country Seat Whether Hamilton's-Bawn shall be turn'd into a
Malt-house or a Barrack

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: ·Sir Arthur Atchinson to his Lady.Thus spoke to my Lady, the Knight full of care,
Let me have your Advice in a weighty affair.
This Hamiltons-Bawn while it stiks on my hand,
I loose by the House what I get by the Land.
But how to dispose of it to the best bidder
For a Barrack or a Malt-house we now must consider.
First let me suppose I make it a Malt house.
Here I have computed the profit will fall t'us;
Ther's Nine hundred pounds for Labour & grain
I encrease it to twelve: So three hundred remain.
A handsome addition for wine and good chear,
Three dishes a day, and three Hogsheads a year;
With a Dozen large Vessells my vault shall be stor'd,
No little scrub Ioynt shall come to my board;
And you and the Dean no more shall combine,
To stint me at night to One bottle of wine;
Nor shall I for his humour permit you to purloyn
A stone and an half of Beef from my surloyn.
If I make it a Barrack the crown is my Tenant
My Dear I have ponder'd again, and again on't.
In poundage and draw·backs I loose half my Rent:
With whatever they give me I must be content;
Or joyn with the Court in every Debate,
And rather then that, I'd loose half my Estate.
Thus ended the Knight: thus began his meek Wife,
It must and it shall be a Barrack my Life;
I'm grown a meer Mopus, no company comes,
·Rum. a Cant word in Ireland. for a poor Country Curate.But a rabble of Tenants and Rusty dull Rum's;
With Parsons what Lady can keep her self clean?
I'm all over daub'd when I sit by the Dean.
om.
om.
But if you will give us a Barrack my Dear,
The Captain I'm sure will always come here.
·Wherever the Dean is mentioned thro'out this Poem. Dean Swift is meant.I then shall not value his Deanship a straw.
For the Captain I warrant will keep him in awe.
And should he pretend to be brisk and alert,
Will tell him that Chaplains must not be so pert:
That men of his Coat shou'd be minding their Pray'rs,
And not among Ladies to give themselves Airs.──
Thus argued my Lady but argued in vain
The Knight his Opinion resolv'd to maintain.
·Hannah. Lady Atchinson's Chamber maid.But Hannah who listen'd to all yṭ had past,
And could not endure so Vulgar a taste;
Assoon as her Ladyship call'd to be dress't
Cry'd──── Madam; why sure my Master's posess'd,
Sir Arthur the Maltster! how fine it will sound?
I'd rather the Bawn were sunk under ground.
But Madam I guesst, there wou'd never come good,
·Darby & Wood. Two of Sṛ Arthur's Managers.When I saw him so often with Darby Wood.
And now my Dream's out; for I was a dream'd,
That I saw an Hugh Rat; o dear how I scream'd!
And after methought, I lost my new shoes;
And Molly she said I shou'd hear some ill news.
Dear Madam had you but the Spirit to teize,
You might have a Barrack when ever you please,
And Madam I always believ'd you so stout,
That for twenty Denyalls you wou'd not give out:
If I had an Husband like him, I portest
Till he gave me my Will, I wou'd give him no rest:
And rather than come in the same pair of Sheets
With such a cross man I wou'd lye in the streets.
But Madam I beg you contrive and invent,
And worry him out, till he gives his Consent.
Dear Madam when 'ere of a Barrack I think
An I were to be hang'd I can't sleep a wink
For if a new Crotchet comes into my Brain
I can't get it out tho' I'd never so fain.
I fancy already a Barrack contriv'd
At Hamiltons Bawn and the Troop is arriv'd.
Of this to be sure Sir Arthur has warning,
And waits on the Capt betimes the next morning.
Now see when they meet how their Honours behave
Noble Captain your Servant────── Sṛ Arthur yr Slave──
You honour me much──── the Honour is mine────
T'was a sad rainy Night, but the Morning is fine────
Pray how does my Lady?──── My Wife·'s at yr service────
I think I have seen her picture by Iervas.────
om.
om.
Good-Morrow good Capṭ not half an Inch farther────
You must be obey'd your Servant Sir Arthur;
My humble respects to my Lady unknown.────
I hope you will use my House as your own.────
Go bring me my Smock and leave off yr prate,
Thou hast certainly gotten a Cup in thy pate.
Pray Madam be quiet what was it I said,
You had like to have putt it quite out of my head.
Next day to be sure the Captain will come
At the head of his Troop with Trumpet & Drum.
Now Madam observe how he marches in State,
The Man with the Kettledrum enters the gate:
Dub dub a dub dub: The Trumpeters follow
Tantara tantara, while all the boys hollow.
See now comes the Captain all daub'd with gold lace;
O law the sweet Gentleman look in his face:
And see how he rides like a Lord of the land,
With a fine flaming Sword that he holds in his hand.
And his Horse the dear Creter it prances & rears
With ribbans in knots at his tail & it's Ears.
At last comes the Troop by the word of command,
Drawn up in our Court, till the Captain cryes stand,
Your Ladyship lifts up the sash to be seen,
(For sure I had dizen'd you out like a Queen:)
The Captain to shew he was proud of the favour,
Looks up to your Window and cocks up his Beaver;
(His Beaver is cock'd, pray Madam mark that,
For a Capain of Horse never takes off his hat,
Because he has never a Hand that is Idle.
For the right holds his Sword, & the left holds his bridle)
Then flourishes thrice his Sword in the Air,
As in Compliment due to a Lady so fair.
How I tremble to think of the blood it has spilt!
Then he low'rs down the point & kisses the Hilt,
Your Ladyship smiles, and thus you begin;
Pray Captain be pleased to alight & walk in,
The Captain salutes you with Congeé profound,
And your Ladyship courtsey's half way to yṛ ground.
Kit run to your Master & bid him come to us,
I'm sure he'l be proud of the Honour you do us.
And Captain you'l do us the favour to stay,
And take a short Dinner here wtḥ us today.
You're heartily welcome, but as for good chear,
You come in the very worst time of the Year.
Had I but expected so worthy a Guest──────
Lord Madam! Your Ladyship sure is in Iest.
You banter me Madam. The Kingdom must grant──
You Officers Captain are so complaisant.──────
Hist Huzzy, I think I hear somebody coming,
No Madam, 'tis only Sir Arthur a humming.
To shorten my Tale (for I hate a long Story)
The Captain at dinner appears in his glory.
·The Doctor. is Doctṛ Ienny, a worthy Clergyman of Armagh─.The Dean the Doctor have humbl'd their pride,
For the Captain's entreated to sitt by yr- Side,
And because he's their Betters you carve for him first.
The Parsons for envy are ready to burst.
The Servants amaz'd are scarce ever able,
To keep off their Eyes, as they wait at ye Table,
And Molly and I have thrust in our nose,
To peep at the Captain in all his fine Cloaths.
Dear Madam be sure he's a fine spoken man,
Do but hear on the the Clergy-men how his tongue ran.
om.
om.
And Madam sais he, if such Dinners you give,
You'l never want Parsons as long as you live;
I ne'er knew a Parson without a good nose,
But the Devil's as wellcome where ever he goes.
G--d d--- me they bid us reform and repent,
But Z---s by their looks, they never keep Lent,
Mister Curate, for all your grave looks I'm afraid,
You cast a Sheep's Eye on her Ladyship's maid.
I wish she wou'd lend you her pretty white hand,
In mending your Gown, and smoothing your band.
For \t·correcting·T·(or·vice·versa\he Dean was so shabby & look'd so like a Ninny
·\cue refers to n.7 above\.That the Capt suppos'd he was curate to Ienny.
When ever you see a Cassock and gown,
An hundred to one but it covers a Clown,
Observe how a Parson comes into a room,
G-- d--- me he hobbles as bad as my Groom.
A Schollard when just from his College broke loose
Can hardly tell how to cry BO to a goose.
Your Novid's and Blutrack's & Omur's & Stuff
By G-- they don't signify this pinch of Snuff.
To give a young Gentleman right Education,
The Army's the only best school in the Nation.
My School master call'd me a Dunce & a fool
But at Cuffs I was always the Cock of ye School.
I never cou'd take to my books for the blood o' me,
And the Puppy confess't, he expected no good o' me.
om.
om.
om.
om.
Now Madam you'l think it a strange thing to say.
But the sight of a Book makes me sick to this day.
Never since I was born did I hear so much Wit
And Madam I laugh't till I thought I shou'd split.
So then you look'd scornfull, & snuf't at ye Dean,
As who shou'd say, Now am I skinny and lean?
But he durst not so much as once open his lipps.
And the Doctor was plaguily down in the hipps.
Thus Merciless Hannah ran on in her talk
Till she heard the Dean call── will yr Ladyship walk?
Her Ladyship answers── I'm Iust coming down,
Then turning to Hannah and fourcing a frown,
Altho' it was plain in her heart she was glad,
Cry'd Huzzy, why sure the wench is gone mad.
Hou cou'd these Chimera's get into yr- brains?
Come hither, and take this old gown for yr pains.
But the Dean if this secret shou'd come to his Ears,
Will never have done wtḥ his Gibes & his Iears.
For your-life, not a word of the matter I charge ye-:
Give me but a Barrack a fig for the Clergy──
